description: From Middle English folwen, folȝen, folgen, from Old English folgian (“to follow, pursue”), from Proto-West Germanic *folgēn, from Proto-Germanic *fulgāną (“to follow”).

entries.meaning: (sometimes attributive) In billiards and similar games, a stroke causing a ball to follow another ball after hitting it.
examples: a follow shot

entries.meaning: (social media) The act of following another user's online activity.
examples: It doesn't take too many follows to become overwhelmed with the deluge of content on Twitter.

verbs.description: follow (third-person singular simple present follows, present participle following, simple past and past participle followed)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To go after; to pursue; to move behind in the same path or direction, especially with the intent of catching.
examples: Synonyms: trail, tail
Antonyms: guide, lead
Follow that car!
She left the room and I followed.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To go or come after in a sequence.
examples: Synonyms: succeed; see also Thesaurus:succeed
Antonyms: precede; see also Thesaurus:precede
B follows A in the alphabet.
We both ordered the soup, with roast beef to follow.
Synonym: pursue
Follow these instructions to the letter.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To live one's life according to (religion, teachings, etc).
(transitive) To understand, to pay attention to.
examples: Do you follow me?

entries.meaning: (transitive) To watch, to keep track of (reports of) some event or person.
examples: I followed the incumbent throughout the election.
My friends don't regularly follow the news.

entries.meaning: (social media, transitive) To subscribe to see content from an account on a social media platform.
examples: Antonym: unfollow
If you want to see more of our articles, follow us on Twitter.

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive) To be a logical consequence of something.
examples: Synonym: ensue
It follows that if two numbers are not equal then one is larger than the other.
If you don't practise proper hygiene, illness is sure to follow.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To walk in, as a road or course; to attend upon closely, as a profession or calling.
